name: TISSUE ENG/PR/MTHD/APP

values.comments:
Tissue engineering demonstrates enormous potential for improving human health. While there is an extensive body of literature discussing the state of the art of tissue engineering, the majority of this literature is descriptive and does little to address the principles that govern the success or failure of an engineering tissue. This course explores principles of tissue engineering, drawing upon diverse fields such as developmental biology, immunology, cell biology, physiology, transport phenomena, material science, and polymer chemistry. Current and developing methods of tissue engineering as well as specific applications are discussed in the context of these principles. There is no required textbook, but literature reviews and journal article analysis are incorporated throughout the course.

Students generally found the content covered in this course to be “interesting,” but “the lack of a main text or reference negatively affected the ability to synthesize this information.” Since “the field is inherently very new and disorganized” and broad, some felt that the material was shallowly covered and that there was little cohesiveness between different topics. Some students wished that the course focused less on biology and more on quantitative problem solving; many equations were presented in the second half of the course but there weren’t many examples to show what they were used for.

Professor Salinas was described by many students as “approachable,” “friendly,” and “very helpful in and out of class.” She created a “relaxed, easygoing environment” and encouraged student participation. However, some students agreed that she was “flustered at times” and “not able to explain a lot of concepts.”

Students generally felt that the workload required for this course was “reasonable,” although extra reading was necessary due to the simplified nature of the material covered in class. Several students complained that they felt unprepared for the exams because Professor Salinas did not provide any information about their format. This is a graduate level course; undergraduates need instructor permission to enroll.
